{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-026-03-A |Item_parent=Acute abdominal pain in a pregnant woman |Item_parent_short=Acute abdominal pain in pregnant women |Rank=A |Title=Knowing how to manage emergency situations related to acute abdominal pain in pregnant women. |Description=Know how to guide the clinical examination and suggest appropriate paraclinical tests during management. |Rubric=Identification of the emergency |Contributors=Louis Marcellin,Philippe Deruelle |Order=3}} Orientation of the clinical examination in the context of acute abdominal pain in pregnant women ==Search for life-threatening etiologies (extreme emergency)== - Obstetrical context - Medical and obstetrical history - Characteristics of pain - Haemodynamic tolerance: BP and pulse - Palpation of the uterus: uterine contracture - [[Genital bleeding during pregnancy SD-111|Metrorrhagia]] - Detection of foetal heart sounds
. ==Extreme emergency eliminated== - Taking the temperature - Abdominal palpation, lumbar fossa - Vaginal touch / speculum: cervical changes / [[Loss of fluid in a preterm pregnant woman SD-109|loss of fluid]] - [[Urine dipstick analysis SD-182|Urine dipstick]]

question.question: What should be done after eliminating the extreme emergency in the context of acute abdominal pain in pregnant women?
question.option_a: Take a detailed medical and obstetrical history
question.option_c: Perform a vaginal touch/speculum examination to check for cervical changes and loss of fluid
question.option_d: Take a detailed abdominal palpation, focusing on the lumbar fossa
